errors.description: The processor did not accept this hold.
This card was declined by the processor.
The processor did not accept the transaction.
The account is already a merchant.
This address could not be verified.
This hold has already expired.

The bank account is already associated with an account -- it cannot be
associated.
Bank account authentication amounts do not match.
Bank account authentication amounts do not match.
Bank account authentication is not in state ``pending``.
The bank account is not associated with the given account.

This bank account has already been marked as invalid/deactivated. It cannot
be used again.

The bank account was tokenized on a different marketplace than the one
used for this request.

The card was tokenized on a different marketplace than the one used for
this request.

The merchant information was created on a different marketplace than the
one used for this request.
This hold has already been captured or voided, and cannot be captured.
This hold has already been captured or voided, and cannot be voided.
This hold has already been captured, which cannot be reversed.

The card is already associated with an account -- it cannot be associated
again.
The card is not associated with the given account.

This card has already been marked as invalid/deactivated. It cannot be used
again.

The card could not be validated -- either the card number or security code
may be wrong.
Debit has already been fully refunded.
An account with the given email address already exists.
The given funding destination is already associated with an account.
The given funding destination is not associated with the account.
The given funding destination cannot have a credit created against it.
The given funding source is already associated with an account.
The given funding source is not associated with an account.

The given funding source cannot have an authorization created against
it. Authorizations are only valid for card-type funding sources.
The given funding source cannot have a debit created against it.
The given funding source cannot have a hold created against it.
The given funding source cannot be refunded.
This hold is not associated with this account.
This hold is not associated with this marketplace.
Marketplace balance is insufficient to issue this credit
Account balance is insufficient to issue this debit
Marketplace escrow balance is insufficient to issue this credit.
Marketplace has already been created.
The account has no valid funding destinations.
The account has no valid funding sources.
Marketplace escrow balance is insufficient to issue this refund.
Bank account authentication is not allowed.

No buyer or merchant info was provided. Either "merchant/merchant_uri" or
"card/card_uri" fields must be present.
Refund amount cannot be greater than the amount of the original debit.
This bank account number is not alpha numeric (ascii). It can not be used.
The routing number provided for the bank account was invalid.
State of debit to refund must be ``succeeded``.

fields.description:
Resolves a particular field of an object (e.g. o.some.random.field). It
will also check if this object is part is part of a cycle as indicated by
context's `cycle` attribute and what to do about it as indicated by
context's `cycle_default` attribute. If SKIP then the spec returns NONE
indicating the spec should be ignored otherwise a ValueError is raised.

`name`
    The name of the field to pull off the object and return. If name is
    None (the default) it is taken from context's `name` attribute. For
    details on how fields are parsed and how they resolve to the attribute
    value(s) of an object see `resolve_field`.

`default`
    Determines how to handle the case where the field cannot be resolved
    for an object which should be either SKIP or NONE. If SKIP then the
    spec will return NONE when the field cannot be resolved otherwise it is
    NONE and an AttributeError is raised.

context's `cycle` attribute and what to do about it as indicated by
context's `cycle_default` attribute. If SKIP then the spec returns NONE
indicating the spec should be ignored otherwise a ValueError is raised.

`name`
    The name of the field to pull off the object and return. If name is
    None (the default) it is taken from context's `name` attribute. For
    details on how fields are parsed and how they resolve to the attribute
    value(s) of an object see `resolve_field`.

`default`
    Determines how to handle the case where the field cannot be resolved
    for an object which should be either SKIP or NONE. If SKIP then the
    spec will return NONE when the field cannot be resolved otherwise it is
    NONE and an AttributeError is raised.
fields.name: state

fields.description:
A key/value collection of aggregated callbacks and statuses where the
key is the status and the value is the number of callbacks for this
event in that state.

occurred.

fields.validate:
URI referencing the customer of the merchant whom the debit is being
done on behalf of. This is different from marketplace. In a
peer-to-peer transaction, there are three parties:

1. Marketplace
2. Seller/Service provider
3. Buyer

This merchant account represents **2**.
fields.name: on_behalf_of_uri

fields.description:
If the resolving URI references a hold then this is hold amount. You can
always capture less than the hold amount (e.g. a partial capture).
Otherwise its the maximum per debit amount for your marketplace.
fields.default:
If the resolving URI references a hold then the default ``amount``
is the ``amount`` associated with that hold. Otherwise no default
is provided and this field is **required**.

endpoints.description:
**NOTE** You'll only need to verify a bank account if you're planning to later
debit that account, which is a functionality only available through our ACH
Debits private beta. Email support@balancedpayments.com to request access.

**NOTE** If you're sending money to a bank account, known as issuing a credit,
you do **NOT** need to verify the bank account

Before you can debit a bank account you need to verify that you have access to
it. Balanced allows you to do this by creating a Verification for a
Bank Account which will result in two random amounts being credited into the
bank account. The amounts of these two deposits must be sent back as
the `amount_1` and `amount_2` params when subsequently updating this
verification. These deposits will appear on the bank accounts statement as
`Balanced verification`. (see `Confirm a Bank Account Verification`_).

If you fail to verify the bank account you must create a new verification and
begin the process again. You can only create one verification at a time and the
trial deposits should show in the bank account within 2 business days.
endpoints.name: bank_account_verifications.create

descriptions.description:
You'll eventually want to be able to credit bank accounts without having to
ask your users for their information over and over again. To do this, you'll
need to create a bank account object.
:
descriptions.name: BankAccount

descriptions.description:
Customers represent businesses or people within your marketplace. You can
associate credit cards, debit cards, bank accounts and transactions,
i.e. refunds, debits, credits.
descriptions.name: Customer

descriptions.description:
Accounts help facilitate managing multiple credit cards, debit cards,
and bank accounts along with different financial transaction operations, i.e.
refunds, debits, credits.
descriptions.name: Account

descriptions.description:
To credit a bank account, you must create a new credit resource.

**NOTE** If you're sending money to a bank account, known as issuing a credit,
you do **NOT** need to verify the bank account.
descriptions.name: Credit

descriptions.description:
**NOTE** You'll only need to verify a bank account if you're planning to later
debit that account, which is a functionality only available through our ACH
Debits private beta. Email support@balancedpayments.com to request access.

**NOTE** If you're sending money to a bank account, known as issuing a credit,
you do **NOT** need to verify the bank account

Before you can debit a bank account you need to verify that you have access to
it. Balanced allows you to do this by creating a Verification for a
Bank Account which will result in two random amounts being credited into the
bank account. The amounts of these two deposits must be sent back as
the `amount_1` and `amount_2` params when subsequently updating this
verification. These deposits will appear on the bank accounts statement as
`Balanced verification`. (see `Confirm a Bank Account Verification`_).

If you fail to verify the bank account you must create a new verification and
begin the process again. You can only create one verification at a time and the
trial deposits should show in the bank account within 2 business days.
descriptions.name: BankAccountVerification

descriptions.description:
"
Currently, Balanced supports only card transactions (`info on ACH debits`_) for
debits. To debit an account, i.e. charge a card, you must create a new debit
resource.
descriptions.name: Debit

descriptions.description:
Holds are a type of authorization that reserves (i.e. holds) a dollar amount
on the customer's credit card, usually within 7 days.

A successful hold can be captured, and as a result, creates a
:ref:`debit <debits>`.
descriptions.name: Hold

descriptions.description:
You can configure events to be published via a ``POST`` to the endpoint of your
choice via callbacks. Once configured, events are accessible via the
:ref:`events <events>` endpoint.
descriptions.name: Event

descriptions.description:
You'll eventually want to be able to charge credit/debit cards without
having to ask your users for their information over and over again. To do
this, you'll need to create a card resource.

To actually charge cards, you must :ref:`debit an account <debits>`.
descriptions.name: Card

descriptions.description:
Issues a refund from a debit. You can either refund the full amount of the
debit or you can issue a partial refund, where the amount is less than the
charged amount.
descriptions.name: Refund

fields.description:
A single level key-value structure where both key and value can only
be strings.

This example shows how to check if a key is in the field:

    {'e[contains]': 'universe'}

While this example shows how to check if a key in the field has a
particular value:

    {'e.rating': 'ultra-shady'}

And of course you can check many key, value pairs for a particular value:

    {'e.rating': 'ultra-shady',
     'e.street': 'band',
     }

values.hold.captured: Occurs whenever a hold is captured.
values.hold.updated: Occurs whenever a hold is updated.
values.debit.succeeded: Occurs whenever a debit is successfully captured or withdrawn.
values.refund.canceled: Occurs whenever a refund is canceled.
values.refund.succeeded: Occurs whenever a refund is successfully captured or deposited.
values.hold.voided: Occurs whenever a hold is voided.
values.account.created: Occurs whenever a new account is created.
values.refund.updated: Occurs whenever a refund is updated.
values.credit.created: Occurs whenever a new credit is created.
values.credit.failed: Occurs whenever a credit is rejected.
values.refund.failed: Occurs whenever a refund is rejected.
values.debit.canceled: Occurs whenever a debit is canceled.

fields.description:
Resolves a particular field of an object (e.g. o.some.random.field). It
will also check if this object is part is part of a cycle as indicated by
context's `cycle` attribute and what to do about it as indicated by
context's `cycle_default` attribute. If SKIP then the spec returns NONE
indicating the spec should be ignored otherwise a ValueError is raised.

`name`
    The name of the field to pull off the object and return. If name is
    None (the default) it is taken from context's `name` attribute. For
    details on how fields are parsed and how they resolve to the attribute
    value(s) of an object see `resolve_field`.

`default`
    Determines how to handle the case where the field cannot be resolved
    for an object which should be either SKIP or NONE. If SKIP then the
    spec will return NONE when the field cannot be resolved otherwise it is
    NONE and an AttributeError is raised.

endpoints.description:
**NOTE** If you're sending money to a bank account, known as issuing a credit,
you do **NOT** need to verify the bank account

Gets the verification for a bank account.
endpoints.name: bank_account_verifications.show

endpoints.description: Missing resource member endpoints use this.
endpoints.name: bank_account_verifications.delete

endpoints.description:
**NOTE** You'll only need to verify a bank account if you're planning to later
debit that account, which is a functionality only available through our ACH
Debits private beta. Email support@balancedpayments.com to request access.

**NOTE** If you're sending money to a bank account, known as issuing a credit,
you do **NOT** need to verify the bank account

Before you can debit a bank account you need to verify that you have access to
it. Balanced allows you to do this by creating a Verification for a
Bank Account which will result in two random amounts being credited into the
bank account. The amounts of these two deposits must be sent back as
the `amount_1` and `amount_2` params when subsequently updating this
verification. These deposits will appear on the bank accounts statement as
`Balanced verification`. (see `Confirm a Bank Account Verification`_).

If you fail to verify the bank account you must create a new verification and
begin the process again. You can only create one verification at a time and the
trial deposits should show in the bank account within 2 business days.
endpoints.name: bank_account_verifications.create

endpoints.description:
**NOTE** You'll only need to verify a bank account if you're planning to later
debit that account, which is a functionality only available through our ACH
Debits private beta. Email support@balancedpayments.com to request access.

**NOTE** If you're sending money to a bank account, known as issuing a credit,
you do **NOT** need to verify the bank account

Before you can debit a bank account you need to verify that you have access to
it. Balanced allows you to do this by creating a Verification for a
Bank Account which will result in two random amounts being credited into the
bank account. The amounts of these two deposits must be sent back as
the `amount_1` and `amount_2` params when subsequently updating this
verification. These deposits will appear on the bank accounts statement as
`Balanced verification`. (see `Confirm a Bank Account Verification`_).

If you fail to verify the bank account you must create a new verification and
begin the process again. You can only create one verification at a time and the
trial deposits should show in the bank account within 2 business days.
endpoints.name: bank_account_verifications.create

descriptions.description:
You'll eventually want to be able to credit bank accounts without having to
ask your users for their information over and over again. To do this, you'll
need to create a bank account object.
:
descriptions.name: BankAccount

descriptions.description:
Customers represent businesses or people within your marketplace. You can
associate credit cards, debit cards, bank accounts and transactions,
i.e. refunds, debits, credits.
descriptions.name: Customer

descriptions.description:
Accounts help facilitate managing multiple credit cards, debit cards,
and bank accounts along with different financial transaction operations, i.e.
refunds, debits, credits.
descriptions.name: Account

descriptions.description:
To credit a bank account, you must create a new credit resource.

**NOTE** If you're sending money to a bank account, known as issuing a credit,
you do **NOT** need to verify the bank account.
descriptions.name: Credit

descriptions.description:
**NOTE** You'll only need to verify a bank account if you're planning to later
debit that account, which is a functionality only available through our ACH
Debits private beta. Email support@balancedpayments.com to request access.

**NOTE** If you're sending money to a bank account, known as issuing a credit,
you do **NOT** need to verify the bank account

Before you can debit a bank account you need to verify that you have access to
it. Balanced allows you to do this by creating a Verification for a
Bank Account which will result in two random amounts being credited into the
bank account. The amounts of these two deposits must be sent back as
the `amount_1` and `amount_2` params when subsequently updating this
verification. These deposits will appear on the bank accounts statement as
`Balanced verification`. (see `Confirm a Bank Account Verification`_).

If you fail to verify the bank account you must create a new verification and
begin the process again. You can only create one verification at a time and the
trial deposits should show in the bank account within 2 business days.
descriptions.name: BankAccountVerification

descriptions.description:
"
Currently, Balanced supports only card transactions (`info on ACH debits`_) for
debits. To debit an account, i.e. charge a card, you must create a new debit
resource.
descriptions.name: Debit

descriptions.description:
Holds are a type of authorization that reserves (i.e. holds) a dollar amount
on the customer's credit card, usually within 7 days.

A successful hold can be captured, and as a result, creates a
:ref:`debit <debits>`.
descriptions.name: Hold

descriptions.description:
You can configure events to be published via a ``POST`` to the endpoint of your
choice via callbacks. Once configured, events are accessible via the
:ref:`events <events>` endpoint.
descriptions.name: Event

descriptions.description:
You'll eventually want to be able to charge credit/debit cards without
having to ask your users for their information over and over again. To do
this, you'll need to create a card resource.

To actually charge cards, you must :ref:`debit an account <debits>`.
descriptions.name: Card

descriptions.description:
Issues a refund from a debit. You can either refund the full amount of the
debit or you can issue a partial refund, where the amount is less than the
charged amount.
descriptions.name: Refund

fields.description:
A single level key-value structure where both key and value can only
be strings.

This example shows how to check if a key is in the field:

    {'e[contains]': 'universe'}

While this example shows how to check if a key in the field has a
particular value:

    {'e.rating': 'ultra-shady'}

And of course you can check many key, value pairs for a particular value:

    {'e.rating': 'ultra-shady',
     'e.street': 'band',
     }

values.credit.succeeded: Occurs whenever a credit is successfully captured or deposited.
values.debit.failed: Occurs whenever a debit is rejected.
values.debit.created: Occurs whenever a new debit is created.
values.credit.canceled: Occurs whenever a credit is canceled.
values.refund.created: Occurs whenever a new refund is created.
values.account.updated: Occurs whenever an account is updated.
values.credit.updated: Occurs whenever a credit is updated.
values.hold.captured: Occurs whenever a hold is captured.
values.hold.updated: Occurs whenever a hold is updated.
values.debit.succeeded: Occurs whenever a debit is successfully captured or withdrawn.
values.refund.canceled: Occurs whenever a refund is canceled.
values.refund.succeeded: Occurs whenever a refund is successfully captured or deposited.
values.hold.voided: Occurs whenever a hold is voided.
values.account.created: Occurs whenever a new account is created.
values.refund.updated: Occurs whenever a refund is updated.
values.credit.created: Occurs whenever a new credit is created.
values.credit.failed: Occurs whenever a credit is rejected.
values.refund.failed: Occurs whenever a refund is rejected.
